Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: 2016 NSF Proposal Writing Workshop; Blacksburg, Virginia; June 27, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports an NSF proposal writing workshop aiming to aid future NSF proposal submitters in communicating clear research objectives and improving proposal quality. Participants will learn guidelines for writing a quality NSF proposal with an emphasis on the research objective. Interactions during the workshop will help build meaningful collaborations. This will positively affect the attendees' academic career and, subsequently, will help develop the nation's human resources. Additionally, when proposals are well written, the reviews tend to be more consistent and NSF panel meetings are more efficient.

This NSF proposal writing workshop will be held on June 27, 2016, at Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, Virginia. It will be collocated with the 44th SME (Society of Manufacturing Engineers) North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the ASME (American Society of Mechanical Engineers) Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2016). Major activities of the workshop include: presentations by NSF program directors, breakout sessions to discuss example research objectives, a group question/answer period, and a conclusions session. Professors and graduate students from across the US will be invited to attend the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An NSF proposal writing workshop was held on June 27, 2016. The workshop was collocated with the 44th SME North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2016). The workshop objective was to aid future NSF proposal submitters in communicating clear research objectives and improving proposal quality. Based on the workshop evaluations, the workshop will positively affect professors and students across the US, which will directly strengthen national human resources. Improved proposal quality will also facilitate consistent, effective proposal review for the CMMI programs.

Intellectual merit

Major activities of the workshop included:

  • presentations by NSF personnel
  • individual activities to practice defining a research objective
  • a group activity to discuss example research summaries
  • a question/answer period with NSF personnel.

Broader impacts

Professors and graduate students from both the US and other countries attended the workshop. They learned guidelines for writing a quality research objective. Interactions during the workshop with colleagues helped foster meaningful collaborations. The relationships developed during the workshop will positively affect the attendees' academic careers and, subsequently, will help develop the nation's human resources. Additionally, by improving the participants' proposals, the panel reviews will be more consistent. This will help in making the NSF panel review meetings run more smoothly.
